Post

Periods How do periods affect bg levels ? I have irregular periods and am either very low or very high. Someone please help 😭

Comments:

Comment 1: I always run high, especially in the morning on my period. I adjust my long acting dose. I also had irregular periods, but I switched to an IUD, which basically got rid of my period. I have maybe 1 or 2 days of spotting a month. That has helped tremendously! I think there are other birth controls that will help make your cycle more regular, too.

Comment 2: Mine tend to run high during my time of the month

Comment 3: Usually for about 4 days before my period I had high BGs, was moody, craving carbs, sweets and salty snacks, then my period would start and my BGs would plummet and I would crash! I had been started on an insulin pump and got help creating a special basal rate just for the premenstrual time. I had to keep track and remember but once I turned it on, it helped with my numbers. Not sure what to do with the irregularity tho…makes it hard to predict but perhaps if your numbers start creeping upward for no apparent reason that is your cue?

Post

How to start GLP-1 and avoid lows? The pharmacist I work with at my doctors office is interested in putting me on a GLP-1 to help with insulin resistance and appetite reduction. I’ve been doing research here and there and see overall great results, mixed with nausea and some bad lows. Has anyone had success starting one of these drugs and avoiding lows? I’ve seen people mention a total daily insulin reduction of 25%-50%. Maybe I reduce basal down 25 or 50% from the get go and see how much the GLP-1 drug contributes and increase insulin from there if needed? Any input is much appreciated!

Comments:

Comment 1: I’ve tried both, no issues with lows. I have a tslim and it will just reduce my basal if needed.

Comment 2: Took 4th dose of 0.25mg today. Was on Lantus + Apidra earlier. Take 0.25mg Ozempic weekly, plus 18U Lantus daily + 2-4 units Apidra if BS spikes over 250. Prior to Ozempic, my BS was wild stayed above 250 usually and will get 3-4 hypos in a day if increased either basal or bolus. Before breakfast I would wake up with BS around 130 and upon walking up to freshen up, before doing anything (like within 15 minutes getting out of bed) eating anything BS would spike to 180... ON FASTING STOMACH. It does not happen anymore \~ high BS spikes are much controlled. Response to short acting insulin is much better. But I get a daily hypo around 6-7 AM if I am not hyper-vigilant. Sucks. Usually I wake up at 9-10 am not before that. But cant afford rn.

Comment 3: I am a T1 who has been on Saxenda for about 2 months. I use O5 and G6. I have had 2 bad lows in this entire time, and honestly, think that the second one came about as a result of alcohol. I was at a music festival at an all inclusive resort with friends who drink a lot and honestly having 2 drinks a day along with edibles over the course of 4 days, by the last night, I had a horrific low that wasn't even registering on G6 and I had to administer glucagon. I do not think that it was my medication, more that blip in my lifestyle radar. (In my normal life, I have like 2 drinks a week, maybe.) When I got home, I told my endo and she had me change some settings in manual mode, but since then, I haven't had any lows. I saw my endo and my A1C decreased from 7.1 to 6.6, my TIR is absurd, like 90%, and I have lost about 15 pounds. This is only 2 months in. I did have side effects in the beginning, head aches, queasiness, I vomited twice mostly due to eating too close to bed time (your stomach empties slower), but overall, it's a pretty big help. I think about it this way. In normies (without obesity, but with a pancreas), there is an organ that secretes all of these hormones to keep us in check. There aren't ONLY (insulin secreting) beta cells in your pancreas, there are 5 cell types that secrete a whole bunch of hormones -glucagon, insulin, somatostatin, ghrelin, and pancreatic polypeptide. For us, our pancreas is destroyed, but by only taking insulin, we are only replacing that one hormone and not the other hormones that have also been taken out as a result of the autoimmune process. My endo also had me not go up to the highest dose, which would have been my next step. I am currently at 2.4 mg daily. It is still working well. Good luck, and hope you don't have any issues finding your med! It's a problem and whatever you do, DO NOT USE COMPOUNDED PRODUCT. Use only the innovator product in pens.

Comment 4: I kept my basal the same and split bolus for meals, that way I can increase/decrease on the second half as needed. Haven't had any problems. Overall lowered my bolus intake probably 30-40%.

T1D spikes and memory How does diabetes affect memory? My father has been a T1D for 30 years and he is 55yrs old. We have noticed the last few years that his memory has declined. His BS levels are regularly all over the place and he easily hits 400 multiple times weekly. He’s had all relevant testing done and all blood work has come back normal. Is his increased forgetfulness likely due to his lack of control. His father has Alzheimer’s and is in his early 80s. Is this even possible at this age? He’s even had neurological testing done and mild decline showed by the doctor was not worried about alz.... He should be getting a pump soon. Any insight?

Comments:

Comment 1: I feel like low BS are destroying my memory. On average for the last few years I’ve had 3-5 lows a day. My doctor says it sounds like depersonalization disorder but we’ll find out in a few weeks when I see a specialist. :/

Comment 2: Hypos over a long period can damage short term memory.

Post

Can't get my bg down ):

Comments:

Comment 1: Could be a few things, maybe you are getting ill? Or maybe you missed your basal injection? Maybe your insulin has gone off. I'd start with changing your insulin if possible. If you have missed the basal insulin, you will need significantly more insulin to remain stable, do that until your next scheduled basal injection, don't double up basal if you are not sure whether you took it or not. If you are ill you will likely need more insulin to remain in range aswell.

Comment 2: It sounds like maybe basal is off? Hope you get it sorted

Sliding Scale Can anyone in here provide me with a humalog sliding scale? I had one and lost it and have already called my primary more than once this just to get insulin filled and don't feel like calling them back again.

Comments:

Comment 1: If you're not getting a response from your phone calls, you might have better luck going down to your doctor's office in person. It wouldn't be reasonable for someone else to tell you how to dose, partly because dosing is so individual and mainly because sliding scale is an older, not-as-effective way of managing blood sugar.

Comment 2: There is no way that someone else can tell you how much insulin to take - we are all different. You really do need to call your doctor. If all you have is a sliding scale, you might want to look for a new doctor, too - that's not a very modern or effective way to manage type 1.

Post

How long do you wait before you give another correction? My son went to bed with a 102 temp last night. Climbed up to 260, I gave him a correction. It’s been two hours and he hasn’t gone down and I just gave him another correction.

Comments:

Comment 1: 2 hours is typically fine as by that time you should be able to see if it’s (starting to) going down or still up.

Comment 2: I wait until there is no IoB aka insulin active time

Comment 3: Generally 2 hours, sometimes 1.5 hours if it’s gone up in that time. My kiddo has a dexcom so can watch closely to see if things start dropping quickly. Sometimes it’s hard to bring down, other hormones are always at play as well as growing bodies that are changing. Just reread that he has a fever.. so, this complicates things further. Keep him well hydrated, and check for ketones. If he has ketones, he’s at risk for DKA.

Comment 4: Get him to run around a bit

Post

Correction dose How long does everyone wait after a meal to take a correction dose if you go to high? I know fast acting can last up to 4 hours. And I heard it was ok to take correction after 3 hours.

Comments:

Comment 1: I am not a doctor. I would say it depends on how your body uses insulin. It also depends on what you ate and it what order you ate your food groups in.

Comment 2: I have the Inpen so it shows me how much active insulin I have. I watch my dex trend and if I'm going up and dont have enough IOB I will correct, keeping in mind my correction factor. My Inpen allows me to put in my current bs and will suggest a correction based on IOB and my correction factor. Sometimes I'll only do a half unit correction but it can be prob within the first hour and a half to two hours if i'm just having a really bad diabetes day.

Comment 3: i typically wait 2 hours! everyone & every meal is different!

Comment 4: I usually wait a bit, but I’m not your doctor, ask them.

Post

Correction doses How long after a correction dose do you take another? For instance, I had lunch today and needed a correction about an hour and a half later as my initial shot was not doing anything. I took 1.5 units and it still does not seem to have helped. It has now been over two hours since that shot. What would you do in this case? I’m on Humalog.

Comments:

Comment 1: Depends what you’ve eaten. If you’ve had some chunky carbs (bread, pasta, potato, p**za), they’ll kick around for a good long while.

Comment 2: I can do a correction dose after 20-30 minutes, but I've experimented a lot so I'm pretty confident when I undershot my dose.

Comment 3: The next time I consume carbs, although BG doesn't come down instantly so be careful.

Can anyone help me with this?

Comments:

Comment 1: I am not low. I left my pump charging while I took a shower. It’s been like this for a couple hours now. I’ve checked my blood sugar and I am not low at all.

Comment 2: Meanwhile you can install an app like xdrip+ on your mobile. You will need your transmitter Id and if it's not your transmitter that's failed then you can still see your bs while you wait for the replacement.

Post

depression how do y all manage diabetes and depression.

Comments:

Comment 1: Poorly!

Comment 2: Go hit the gym, by the time you get in good shape you won’t be as depressed and diabetes will be easier to take care of. You will have a big confidence boost because you look and feel better. Go watch David Goggins and get off the couch

Comment 3: Therapy

Comment 4: If you are seriously depressed, seek help. I never understood mental health until it got me. Some things that helped me: * fuck social media, it’s a poison. Especially Facebook and its ilk. Just remove them from your phone. Even Reddit if you find it toxic. * meet up with friends. Board games in the pub, social bike rides, basketball, whatever is your thing go do that WITH FRIENDS * meet up with NOT friends. This might just be other social groups that aren’t so close. Could be social bike ride, or volunteering, or something like park run. An important part of our human psyche is being connected to the broader community. * walk in nature, looking ahead, up, around. * join the gym, or a sport or something that works for you(yes this may overlap the previous items) * make sure you sleep enough. I wish you well! 💜

Comment 5: Type 1s NEEEEEEEEEEEEED a therapist

Comment 6: It’s difficult. I’ve struggled with it on and off. A few things that help me: 1. I always check to see if I’m low whenever I start to have an existential crisis. Cuz I usually am lol 2. I hold onto the feelings of success. Good blood sugars, drops in a1c. Feeling good during exercise. I try to remember those, and I try to forgive myself for the bad times. No one’s perfect. 3. Try not to think about it too deeply unless you’re in a safe space (talking to a therapist/friend). It can get overwhelming. Take it day by day. 4. Give yourself a pat on the back. You deal with so much. And you’re still here. You’re doing great! I think that having a chronic conditions has helped me in some ways. I’m careful about my diet, I know my body well, I can build close friendships and community with other diabetics, I can provide empathy to my patients when other nurses can’t because they don’t get it. Im an overall more patient and empathetic person in general. It sucks, I wouldn’t wish it on anyone, but it’s not always horrible. I still have a good amount of control over my life and body. Idk I try to just stay positive, and when I’m having bad moments, I reach out to friends or family (or this subreddit) for support.

Can Apple Watch 7 provide continuous glucose monitoring? My friend was recently diagnosed as a T1DM and was placed on Abbott's libre sensor Recently I was casually chatting with my dad who told me Apple was planning to have continuous glucose monitoring in Apple Watch 7 (forgive me if everyone knew this already, haha, Apple watch hasn't been something I've had my eyes on so far) Just curious... Is this even possible? I was told most continuous glucose monitoring devices require some form of skin pricking to allow the glucose in the body to be tested... if Apple watch can do it by just strapping it on.. that's gonna be a game changer!

Comments:

Comment 1: It was expected on this years update, but it seems to have been pushed back at least a year. I use Libre myself, and I'm looking forward to getting an Apple watch when it can provide glukose monitoring

Comment 2: The other guy is right. It won’t be implemented on this years model, because the medical supplier of the tech still needs to do human trials with it, to determine accuracy and validity, so it won’t be ready for watch 7 by September [non-invasive glucose monitor ](https://appleinsider.com/articles/21/07/14/apple-supplier-launches-non-invasive-glucose-monitor-health-sensor-tech)

Comment 3: Basically, no. :D The method they want to use wouldn't be accurate enough as far as I've heard.

Comment 4: Apple registered a patent for this so is doable. But I have big doubts BigFood and BigPharma will allow such technology widely available to people... It's not about T1D but about millions of people seeing in real-time the effect of their food. That would spell the end of processed food and it will also affect BigPharma sales afterwards...

Comment 5: I very much doubt the administration would allow it to be approved. It will cut $$$ from the companies that donate quite a lot.

Can type 1 diabetics get lasik eye surgery? I’ve been thinking about this process for years even before my diagnoses. I know that type 1 can affect your eyes so I was curious if this is still possible for diabetics? Wanted to ask you friends first before I ask about it at my next eye doctors appointment. Thanks!

Comments:

Comment 1: Yup I got it. It was super easy, no regrets.

Comment 2: Some doctors disagree. I got it done 18 years ago. Love it. Still don’t need glasses though my vision isn’t quite as perfect as it was but I am over 40.

Comment 3: I was told by my optician that we’re not allowed to get it. The eyes change too much and it would be useless…but I see the other commenters say they got it? Interesting

Comment 4: My ophthalmologist said any doc wiling to do it on a diabetic is incompetent. The risk far out weigh the benefit is what I was told, HOWEVER I personally would still consider it if I could find a eye doc who is willing near me! I only have a stigmatism, vision is good, so I’m not sure if this is the reason he said the benefit doesn’t out weight the risk 🤷🏻‍♀️

Post

Cant wait to get hell from my endo We aren’t gona talk about my time in range. Especially my time out of range. I have an appointment in a month, im expecting my a1c to be around a 7, which for some people is a huge goal, and mine was touching almost 10 at one point, so im happy with a 7, would be happier with UNDER a 7, but I’ll take what i can get. But now that I’ve touched 5.8 ONCE, my endo expects more of me. Im in my early 20s, female, hormones fluctuate every day, sometimes it just doesn’t work out in my favor. On MDI, dont want the “you should get a pump” lecture from her, but i know im gona get it. My appointment is in a little over a month, if anyone has any tips to bring my a1c down, even just .1, let me know. I cook 95% of my meals, they’re all fairly low carb, i try to stay active,& i take insulin when i should, dexcom settings 80-150. Im assuming I’ve just had bad luck the past few months, but any tips at all, even for just the slightest drop, would be appreciated. Trying to stay easy on myself, but being lectured by my non t1 endo to “do better” is honestly the worst part of this whole thing& i am NOT looking forward to it. Im starting to feel my yearly burnout coming on 🫠

Comments:

Comment 1: honestly… it sounds like you’re doing all you can on MDI and i’m sorry to say if you really wanna take your control to the next level, tandem’s control iq (or i guess omnipod also) will be a massive improvement. it helps curb highs and mitigate lows. it’s the best available.

Comment 2: I'm on mdi and expecting the same conversation this week at my annual review. Last time I was told to raise it because the a1c being low was due to having os many hypos. I am not going on pump either and won't use libre due to false alarming and inaccurate readings. I know in raising my a1c I stopped prebolus ing as far in advance, from 20 mins to 5. So that's the first thing I can work on. Could you do this? I doubt it would show up so soon though. But other than thst my bg has been massively out of range with huge unpredictability over the last few weeks, the insulin doesn't seem to be working and is taking absolutely ages to work even with high activity.I reordered new pens in case the ones I have are not as effective (??), Its a marathon not a sprint tho, this is lifelong and the last 6 weeks are a drop in a big ocean. Ultimately this conversation probably won't yield me anything much i dont know lol so it's not that relevant whether I get told off or not.

Comment 3: Time for some boundaries with your endo. A couple of key points: 1. They work FOR YOU. You DO NOT work for them. 2. You can fire them when they stop working for you. 3. You can tell them "I will discuss with you getting a pump WHEN AND IF I decide it's best for me. 4. I am an adult and I will not be lectured like I am a child. 5. When they decide they know more than you, start pushing for a pump again, or do anything else to violate your boundaries, tell them "okay, we're done here", get up, walk out of the office, and find a new endo. I've been diabetic for 21 years and have fired more doctors than I can to think about. It's scary the first time but, I promise, it's also very empowering.

Comment 4: MDI for 35 years, pumps are no interest to me. A low a1c is not a good gauge of control (I have had an a1c of 7.1 with a 90% time in range). Do what WORKS for you, mentally and physically. It might be worth mentioning to your endo that you are working hard to keep your numbers where they are, and are happy with them not being worse. If they mention pumps, just be overly blunt and cut them off with “that is not for me”. You are doing your best, keep doing that, everything else will come so long as your trying, it just sometimes takes longer than expected.

Comment 5: Endos wanna pretend there’s a cute little algebra equation that we use every single day that hits every single time when we know it literally almost never works that way. They think this disease is some cookie cutter shit and it’s definitely nothing close to just some simple math. I ate peanut butter before bed once and was high all night. My endo asked me if I covered for the peanut butter and I said I sure as shit did. *cue pikachu shocked face*. The math didn’t math so she thought it was best to change ALL my ratios for all the time because it didn’t make sense to her!! GTFO. I told her I wasn’t doing that, told her what prescriptions I needed refilled, and told her I MIGHT try one of her suggestions that came from whatever magic fake ass diabetes calculator she uses. I consulted my magic 8 ball later - I was better off that way. I didn’t quite say I dose myself based off ~ViBeS~ last time I went in, but I did say I relied a lot on how I felt, and most days I feel different than I did the day before. Even with a good amount of routine, I still have a busy life and shits always changing, like you said. Whatever worked yesterday ain’t gonna cut it today, but might work almost too well tomorrow. I got that good ol pump recommendation too (I used one for 13 years - I’m good on all that) and told her so. Got the “oH aRe U sUrE it can do x, y, z and a buncha other things you already know!!” I just told her no and said it would be fat chance in hell since my insurance hardly covers my CGMs. The insurance excuse got her off that topic real quick, hopefully your endo will hop off if you end up having to pull the “insurance hates diabetics” card too. Remember, “yes” and “no” are complete sentences - especially when you get asked the BS passive aggressive questions like “do you think what you’re doing is working for you even though your A1c is 7.2?” And “wanna get a pump because it might lower that 7.2 a1c?” Yes I do, and no I don’t, next please. You got this dude! You know you more than anyone, and endos are really only here to help us get the supplies we need to keep doing what we know works best for us! Good luck :)

Comment 6: I count myself unbelievably lucky that my Endo has been positive and supportive so far instead of acting like a scolding nanny. My diabetes educator was pretty patronizing but I was fortunately only required to have one session with her.

Post

Let's just think a little please Can we all just start considering that everyone's t1 experience is different. We all don't fit in the same bubble. Some of us have a hard time, through no fault of our own, keeping everything in check. I, for instance, am extremely brittle. I could have the best handle on my glucose and still wake up the next day in a fill blown DKA. I was also neglected as my mother when it came to diabetes as a child. I dont have the comfort of being able to just control my body in the textbook way. I have an A1C of 7, but I still get infections and I get sick easily. My docs tell me it's because I had a history of uncontrolled diabetes as a very young child. Let's please consider that we aren't all the same before berating someone who is having a difficult time. We should all be there and understanding towards each other. There is never a need to be unpleasant to someone who is suffering or venting.

Comments:

Comment 1: 100% sorry for your tough time wish you nothing but the best i also have other medical issues before type 1 that i also have to worry about which can cause issues with my type 1 but again hope all goes well and your feeling better soon

Comment 2: Preach!!! Big hugs friend, take care. Lots of love, and virtual hugs.

Comment 3: So basically all this means someone was hard on you because you could be managing your condition better, and that hurt your feelings? Why don't you just say that

Comment 4: Completely and entirely in agreement with you here! I was just talking about this exact situation the other day between individuals with diabetes and chronic illnesses in general. Living with diabetes or any chronic illness is terrible and impacts everyone differently. We all handle and treat our illnesses the best we can. People need to be supportive first and offer advice if it is asked for. Do not come onto this platform to tell others how they should or should not be handling their illness unless they want your help. There is a lot of literature that goes into the psychosocial aspects of diabetes and these behaviors have consistently been reported as harmful. Offer support, not criticism. Take care OP and everyone else, we all got this illness.

Comment 5: I know exactly what you describe as I've been doing insulin for a long time and others, no matter how good their intentions, cannot possibly appreciate, let alone understand, what we go through. I had one doc explain to me how they had a loaner pump filled with saline and wore it for a week so they could understand what it's like to be T1D... Congratulations, your A1c 7 is very good (that's a 3 month average of about 132 mg/dL). I recall as a high school kid barely able to sit in class for the hour before I had to run to the rest room to urinate and when I was done drink water non-stop before the next class (only 10 minutes between classes). The ridicule I received from classmates was non-stop. But I got through it... Fortunately now I have a sensor and pump and regardless of how poor my control may have been over 50 years ago, I'm fine and enjoy everything -- It's Wonderful Life. What I still do, is eat smaller amounts of food with meals and snacks to avoid spikes (and larger insulin doses) and continue to be active especially walks, hikes and bike rides. Live Long and Prosper : }

Comment 6: I’m interested in this. I will do a literature search on impact of poor type one control as a child and it causing brittle diabetes as an adult. I’ve not heard of this. From my understanding brittle diabetes is when the sugar swings high and then low frequently. You seem to have good glycaemic control so I wonder if something else is at play.

Can T1D’s use creatine? I’m starting to get into weight lifting and want to take creatine but don’t know if it’s safe for diabetics. Does anyone have any experiences/advice with it? Thanks!

Comments:

Comment 1: It’s fine. Perks is creatine needs insulin to be absorbed so you can…make sure it gets absorbed (it’s why regular folks take it with juice, to spike insulin, we don’t have to do that)

Comment 2: Yes, I take it .everyday.

Post

How does my bg keep going up I’ve been sick 2 days now and haven’t had an appetite so the last time I consumed anything was yesterday at 1pm it’s now 11:14am the next day and my bg is going up outta nowhere. How is this even possible?

Comments:

Comment 1: Illness will do that. Your liver releases glucose to fuel the antibodies, which fight off illness.

Comment 2: I'm sure you know this, but just in case… remember to check your ketones and follow sick day rules if you see any.

Comment 3: I thing when not eating the breaks uses stored fat for energy. When there is no longer stored fat it turns to muscle for energy. I believe in type 1 diabetics the body does not detect insulin that is injected manually or through an insulin pump or other means. I believe in a normal person without type 1 diabetes it's always a counterbalance insulin glucose insulin glucose whenever needed. I believe for type 1 diabetics because the body does not detect the insulin but knows it needs energy it will start breaking down stored fat or muscle whichever is available. That causes your blood sugar to rise. The liver does have stored glucose most of the time I believe that is for emergency situations. I think sometimes that is why some people that have hypoglycemia events that are real bad can come out of it briefly and sometimes are able to get something like sugar or whatever. But it's definitely something you cannot count on because sometimes it doesn't happen for everyone. So just be careful small microbolices like others have recommended is the best bet.

Post

How I learned I had T1D So let’s jump into this story so I think it was around the beginning of September I started to get really thirsty it wasn’t to bad at first and I didn’t complain but around the middle of that month is when it started to rapidly change I got so unbearably thirsty that I actually begged my parents to get me a 1 gallon water jug for me I ended up getting it and I would refill that thing at least 4 times a day or more with no relief from the thirst. With all that water came me having to pee A LOT I would go almost every 10-20 minutes school was absolute hell they refused to let me refill my water bottle or to let me go to the bathroom I had to hold it until I was in so much pain I was in tears I would go to the nurse and tell her something was wrong but she just told me that I was trying to skip class and go home early I would go in the bathroom stall and cry my eyes out this went on for pretty much two months until the end of November came around it was thanksgiving break and I was home from school nobody was home that day so I took that opportunity to drink everything in sight until suddenly around 3 o,clock I started to have feelings of acid reflux or so I thought they were so bad and painful I called my older sister on my iPad and told her how much pain I was in and that I wanted somebody to come home of course she couldn’t because she lives in a different state but she was the only one that would answer my calls after about one hour of talking to her I hung up and took a nap I woke back up at 5 with the worst feeling in my chest like burning and acid I coul barely move my body without the paw increasing so I crawled out into the living room and still nobody was home at that point I crawled onto the couch and laid there almost lifeless until someone arrived at 8 I told my grandma that I wasn’t feeling good snatch that I think I should go to the ER and she replied with that they would say the same exact thing that it was just acid reflux and it would be a waste of time and money. I rolled over and cried into a pillow I accidentally cried myself to sleep and woke up around 10 and starter to vomit over and over I eventually stopped and crawled back into bed for the night The night was restless I would wake up every one hour sweating hot, needing to go to the bathroom, and in so much pain I would throw up until I had nothing left in my stomach this happened all night until 4 am when I woke up unable to breathe I was gasping for air so much that it felt like my chest would burst I made it into my grandparents room and woke her up telling her I couldn’t breathe she woke up and decided to take me because she thought I had covid so we rushed into the ER I was barely clinging to Consciousness and was so shaky I could barely stand I was still holding back the urge to vomit a really kind nurse asked me if I needed a wheelchair and I nodded my head as that was all I could do after a few moments another lady came out to take me to get my vitals she was the most horrible lady I’ve ever met she looked me up and down with disgusting her eyes and asked me why I was in a wheelchair I was so shocked I didn’t know what to say not that I could say anything at all once we were in a room she repeatedly told me to calm down and stop breathing so fast and hard I tried to mumble at the words I’m sorry to her but my voice was cracking and my throat was so dry she looked at me and told me she didn’t know what was wrong with me Suddenly another doctor came in in the moment he came in he had a look on his face that he knew some thing that we didn’t he immediately asked for a glucose meter and when he checked my blood sugar his jaw dropped my sugar was around 900 she looked around everyone in the room and immediately started asking them to get an ambulance on the way right now he told my grandma that he didn’t know how I was still conscious The ambulance arrived and it took me an hour away to a children’s hospital where I was put in the PICU for seven days it was really hard I had a lot to learn about how my life is about to change I had to have help with almost everything walking and going to the bathroom eating etc. after seven days I got to go home and I’ve been doing great ever since I was dying on a cellular level and not one person cared up until it was almost to late I just want to say please take you kids seriously they know when something is wrong.

Comments:

Comment 1: [removed]

How do you tell the difference between why the insulin isn’t working? So I have only been diagnosed with type 1 diabetes for just over a year now. I’m on humulog on the tandem tslim and dexcom. It’s hard to describe my question but how do you know it your insulin isn’t working due to a bad site or the insulin is dead? Or you just are being a little resistance at the moment? Like is it really just trial and error and just guess which reason is why you (I) won’t come down? How do you tell the difference between all those? And or if the meal I have just sucked and my timing of blousing was just crappy?

Comments:

Comment 1: Im skeptical of "acute insulin resistance". The insulin is doing something, it's fighting a protein spike, fighting delayed carbs because of fat, fighting dehydration, or fighting blood sugar from stress. Enough insulin will bring it down. Check the site, if insulin isn't leaking out there's a good chance it's getting in. Wait a few hours and change it if it's still fucked.

Comment 2: With my daughter, we always think site first. How long has it been on? If you just put it on, maybe the cannula is bent. Has it been on for 5 days, probably site has gone bad. Did you just change the reservoir, how long has the insulin been open? We also keep one or two unopened pens, just for emergencies. If we think it is the insulin, get out a pen a d see what happens. Really it is trial and error, but depending on site age and when you opened your last vial, you can make a good guess. We have not run into her suddenly having Issues with insulin working g. Hope that helps.

Comment 3: Take your hands and gently wipe them all around the adhesive on your site. If you smell insulin, in your hands, that is a leak/tunneling. Change your site. If your site hurts a lot, change your site. If your site feels loose, change your site. Sites often aren’t suitable anymore well before they seem totally ready to come off. My sites can last anywhere from 2-5 days depending on where they are and what I’m doing. Usually 3-4. Make sure you have enough infusion sets so you aren’t unnecessarily rationing infusion sets if your doctors and insurance will allow it. With respect to your last question, site issues are easiest to diagnose. The rest is much harder. Count carbs, pay attention to if your meal was fatty or had lots of protein in it (may require more insulin), and whether you have been actively lately.

Comment 4: Rage bolus. I'm kidding but for real, if a rage bolus doesn't do anything then the insulin is bad. It's a horrible idea and we all know we shouldn't do it... that said, I am who I am and I'll rage if I want to. But in all seriousness, figuring out what is wrong is not as important as getting blood sugar in range. If something isn't working, I will rip it all out and start fresh instead of experimenting on myself and staying high.

Comment 5: Give yourself an injection with the same insulin - do you come down? If you do it probably the site, if you don’t it’s probably the insulin or infection.

Comment 6: I am ten and a half days late to your party. Here's a cupcake. So if you notice rather than a series of checkpoints each poster at this point only states one thing to check (the funniest always being insulin is bad. insulin is good for 28 days out of the fridge). So, is this a regular issue? What sites do you use? Autosoft, varisoft, trusteel? Days between rotations? Build? Gender (and biological gender because periods matter). Do you drink heavily/binge drinking? Drug use? Type of carbs usually consumed? Hours between large meals? If you aren't comfortable answering some of these (look at my history, I have more than once admitted to being a T1 alcoholic), DM me. but some of the advice on this thread is one pronged and I feel like you need a troubleshooting guide.

How do you treat BG with alcohol consumption? Hi there, I figure I could look this up in the books but I figured since everyone is different, how do you guys treat your Diabetes when drinking? I've never drank alcohol in more than a few sips, and my friend has a party in a couple weeks and wants me to drink with him. How should I care for myself before, during, and after?

Comments:

Comment 1: Hi, current college student. I’m not of legal drinking age yet so I haven’t gone balls to the walls or anything, but I’ve also been trying to safely figure out how to do this. Definitely go into it with something substantial in your stomach. I usually go for something fatty and protein based, eggs and hash browns are my go to. Stay hydrated before/during/after. Basic drinking protocol. I usually try to make sure I have a CGM in and working so I can spot trouble ahead of time. The biggest problem you’ll probably have is lows, probably hours after drinking while your liver is still busy metabolizing what you’ve drank. You can either be really slack about your blousing during the night, I’ll bolus for any meals I have, but small stuff, candy, mixers, I’ll usually leave until the end of the night. I usually try to do this by including a mixed drink or cup of punch a for every few beers/shots I have. If this seems too cavalier for you, I’ve had lots of success having 15-25 carbs of a snack before bed. I try to pack it in whatever bag I take with me, usually a ziplock bag of oreos or thin mints. I’d also recommend an emergency snack just in case you do dip and have nothing on hand. These strategies are really important because glucagons do not work while your body is processing alcohol. When in doubt, aim high, because this isn’t the time to pass out because of a hypo. Have somebody that can recongnize your symptoms really well, this is also really tricky because being low looks and sounds and feels a lot like being drunk. Godspeed.

Comment 2: Insulin affects liver release of glycogen which may cause low. Also according to some studies but not all that confirmed is alcohol affects insulin sensitivity. So you may have to give more increasing risk of hypos. Be aware you may not recognize hypos while drinking m. So you should eat more food and risk being high vs low.
